marketNews.title: US Treasury Secretary Bessent says de-escalation of trade war is China’s responsibility
marketNews.content: The United States Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Monday (28 April) that the de-escalation of the trade war is the responsibility of the Chinese government, noting that China’s exports to the United States are larger than the reverse. On Sunday (27 April), Bessent also said he was not aware that President Donald Trump had spoken with President Xi Jinping about tariff negotiations. Previously, Trump on the previous week claimed that the United States was talking with China to reach a tariff deal, a claim that was denied by the Chinese government.

marketNews.title: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi warns against yielding to U.S. tariff pressure
marketNews.content: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, speaking at a BRICS meeting on Monday (28 April), warned that countries hit by U.S. tariffs should not give in to tariff threats. Wang said that de-escalation would only encourage the "bully" to act further. On Tuesday (29 April), the Chinese Foreign Ministry released a video pledging that the Chinese government would not succumb to U.S. tariff pressure, claiming the move was also for the good of the world.

marketNews.title: Indonesian government bonds face first monthly net foreign outflow in five months
marketNews.content: Bloomberg reported that Indonesia’s government bond market in April 2025 could see its first monthly net foreign outflow since November 2024, as investor confidence erodes due to global economic instability and a weakening rupiah. According to the Ministry of Finance data as of 22 April 2025, Indonesian government bonds experienced a net foreign outflow of USD 221 million since the start of the month.

marketNews.title: LG to increase Indonesia battery-cell plant investment by US$1.7 billion
marketNews.content: Indonesia’s Minister of Investment and Investment Acceleration, Rosan Roeslani, said on Tuesday (29 April) that LG remains committed to investing in the electric-vehicle battery supply chain in Indonesia and will increase its investment by US$1.7 billion in a joint battery-cell plant with Hyundai in West Java, bringing total investment in the project to US$2.8 billion. LG has not commented on the claim. The statement follows a consortium led by LG that a week earlier withdrew from the battery-cell supply chain project with the Indonesian government and state-owned enterprises.

marketNews.title: Rosan Roeslani says Apple may increase investment and add three new vendors in Indonesia
marketNews.content: Indonesia’s Minister of Investment and Acceleration, Rosan Roeslani, said on Tuesday (29 April) that Apple Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL) is likely to increase its investment in Indonesia, with three additional vendors expected to join the country’s supply chain. Roeslani also said that products previously outsourced from China could now be sourced from Indonesia. Apple has not commented on the claim. Previously, Apple agreed to a US$300 million investment in Indonesia as part of a local content certificate (TKDN) agreement.

marketNews.title: GOOD to pay 2024 dividend of IDR 350 billion (9.5 % per share)
marketNews.content: Garudafood Putra Putri Jaya (GOOD) will distribute a 2024 dividend of approximately IDR 350 billion, or IDR 9.5 per share, representing a 56 % dividend-payout ratio and an implied dividend yield of 2.4 % on Tuesday (29 April). The cum-date is on the regular market and negotiation on 5 May 2025, with payment on 21 May 2025.

marketNews.title: ASGR to pay 2024 dividend of IDR 93 billion (45 % payout)
marketNews.content: Astra Graphia (ASGR) will distribute a 2024 dividend of IDR 93 billion, or a 45 % payout ratio, implying a final dividend of IDR 50 per share and a 5.9 % final dividend yield on Tuesday (29 April). The cum-date is not yet known, with payment scheduled for 27 May 2025. Previously, ASGR paid an interim dividend of IDR 19 per share in October 2024.

marketNews.title: TPIA to add seven new vessels in 2025, total fleet to reach 15
marketNews.content: Chandra Asri Pacific (TPIA), through its subsidiary PT Chandra Shipping International, plans to add seven new vessels in 2025, bringing the total fleet to 15 vessels. The move aims to strengthen the logistics ecosystem and increase maritime service capacity. PT Chandra Shipping International is part of PT Chandra Daya Investasi, a TPIA subsidiary focused on infrastructure investment. In February 2025, TPIA said PT Chandra Daya Investasi was considering an IPO on the Indonesia Stock Exchange.

marketNews.title: PIPA to be acquired by PT Morris Capital Indonesia (57.37 % stake)
marketNews.content: Multi Makmur Lemindo (PIPA) announced that PT Morris Capital Indonesia intends to acquire a 57.37 % stake in the company from the controlling and majority shareholders. The transaction value and closing timeline are still under negotiation. After completion, PT Morris Capital Indonesia will become the new controlling shareholder of PIPA and will conduct a mandatory tender offer in accordance with applicable regulations.

tickerNews.title: BMRI 1Q25 Net Profit +4 % YoY, in line with expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Mandiri (BMRI) recorded net profit of IDR 13.2 trillion in 1Q25, a 4 % year-over-year increase and a 4 % quarter-over-quarter decline, matching the consensus estimate of 23 % of 2025F. Asset quality remained sound, but a low net interest margin (NIM) and higher operating expense (OPEX) were noted. Net profit growth matched the rise in Pre-provision Operating Profit, which was supported more by Non-Interest Income (+15 % YoY) than by Net Interest Income (+6 % YoY).

tickerNews.title: BMRI asset quality: CoC 0.9 % and LAR 7.2 % in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: Bank Mandiri’s asset quality remained solid with credit cost (CoC) at 0.9 % in 1Q25 (vs. 1.1 % in 1Q24 and 0.6 % in 4Q24), better than the 2025 guidance range of 1-1.2 %. Non-performing loans (NPL) stayed at 1.2 % (vs. 1.2 % in 1Q24, 1.1 % in 4Q24). The loan-loss-ratio (LAR) rose slightly to 7.2 % (vs. 8.4 % in 1Q24, 6.8 % in 4Q24) due to temporary restructuring of corporate clients in the nickel sector. Despite the low CoC, management kept the 2025 CoC guidance because of high uncertainty.

tickerNews.title: BMRI NIM pressure and 2H25 recovery outlook
tickerNews.content: The net interest margin (NIM) fell as interest expense rose 24 % YoY in 1Q25 while the bank-only cost of funds (CoF) increased to 2.38 % (vs. 2.07 % in 1Q24 and 2.31 % in 4Q24). The bank-only loan yield slipped to 7.64 % (vs. 7.73 % in 1Q24 and 7.85 % in 4Q24) because of lower corporate-segment yields after the SOFR decline. Consequently, NIM was 4.8 % in 1Q25 (vs. 5.1 % in 1Q24, 5.3 % in 4Q24), below the 2025 guidance range of 5-5.2 %. Management reiterated the 1H25 low-NIM outlook and expects recovery in 2H25 as liquidity improves from lower BI rates and higher government spending.

tickerNews.title: BMRI OPEX spikes to IDR 15.2 trillion in 1Q25
tickerNews.content: Operating expenses rose sharply to IDR 15.2 trillion in 1Q25 (+16 % YoY, –19 % QoQ), continuing the trend seen in 4Q24. The increase was driven by a 19 % YoY rise in labour costs, which management attributed to higher incentives and bonuses—especially at regional offices—to boost cheap-deposit (CASA) growth. The higher OPEX pushed the cost-to-income (CIR) ratio to 40.8 % (vs. 38.2 % in 1Q24, 47.9 % in 4Q24). Management aims to keep the ratio below 40 % for the remainder of the year (2024 target 40 %).

tickerNews.title: GOTO 1Q25 pro-forma adjusted EBITDA of IDR 393 billion
tickerNews.content: GoTo (GOTO) reported pro-forma adjusted EBITDA of IDR 393 billion in 1Q25 (vs. a loss of IDR 101 billion in 1Q24 and a positive IDR 399 billion in 4Q24). The pro-forma net loss narrowed to IDR 276 billion in 1Q25 (vs. a loss of IDR 420 billion in 1Q24, 1.1 trillion loss in 4Q24).

tickerNews.title: KLBF 1Q25 net profit up 12 % YoY
tickerNews.content: Kalbe Farma (KLBF) posted net profit of IDR 1.1 trillion in 1Q25, a 12 % YoY increase and 25 % QoQ rise, slightly above the 31 % consensus estimate. Revenue grew to IDR 8.8 trillion (+6 % YoY, +5 % QoQ), matching the 25 % consensus. Operating margin rose to 15.6 % (vs. 14.6 % in 1Q24, 13.9 % in 4Q24) as gross margin improved to 41.6 % (vs. 39.7 % in 1Q24, 41 % in 4Q24).

tickerNews.title: BNGA 1Q25 net profit up 7.4 % YoY
tickerNews.content: Bank CIMB Niaga (BNGA) posted net profit of IDR 1.8 trillion in 1Q25 (+7.4 % YoY, +6.6 % QoQ), slightly above the 26 % consensus. Operating profit was supported by a 36 % YoY decline in provisions (to IDR 316 billion, –4.2 % QoQ) and a fall in credit cost to 0.46 % (vs. 0.8 % in 4Q24, 0.82 % in 1Q24). Management said the CoC decline was a one-off, and it will normalise to about 1 % by end-2025. NIM was 3.99 % in 1Q25 (vs. 4.2 % in 1Q24, 3.88 % in 4Q24) and loan-yield was 8.35 % (vs. 8.23 % in 4Q24, 8.64 % ) despite ​

tickerNews.title: MYOR 1Q25 net profit down 38 % YoY
tickerNews.content: Mayora Indah (MYOR) reported net profit of IDR 689 billion in 1Q25, a 38 % YoY decline and a 30 % QoQ decline, below the 21 % consensus. The decline was driven by a 36 % YoY drop in operating profit to IDR 846 billion (-36 % YoY,-28 % QoQ) and a -36 % YoY contraction in gross margin to 21.9 % (vs. 27.8 % in 1Q24, 20.9 % in 4Q24). OPEX = IDR 1.3 trillion (+18 % YoY, +31 % QoQ). Revenue grew to IDR 9.9 trillion (+13 % YoY, –5 % QoQ, matching the 25 % consensus).

tickerNews.title: LPPF 1Q25 net profit up 97 % YoY
tickerNews.content: Matahari Department Store (LPPF) posted a net profit of IDR 643 billion in 1Q25, equal to 78 % of 2024 profit and 95 % of 2023 profit. The result matches management’s guidance that pro-forma pro-profit - more than 600 billion IDR > ​
